head.title: Political Briefing; Hoping for Easy Win, But Reality Intrudes

hedline.hl1: Political Briefing; Hoping for Easy Win, But Reality Intrudes

abstract.p: Poll shows that Sen Rick Santorum, freshman Pennsylvania Republican, holds 2-to-1 lead over Repr Ron Klink, Democratic challenger; campaign finance report shows that Santorum has nearly 8-to-1 lead in campaign finances (S)

block.p: Democrats looking to regain control of the United States Senate this fall had high hopes in the spring that they could deny a second term to Rick Santorum, a Republican freshman from Pennsylvania. Democrats looking to regain control of the United States Senate this fall had high hopes in the spring that they could deny a second term to Rick Santorum, a Republican freshman from Pennsylvania. He squeaked into office in 1994 with 49 percent of the vote and the conventional wisdom was that he was too conservative for a state with more Democrats than Republicans and had done little since his election to improve his standing with voters.

President Clinton flew into Philadelphia on Monday to campaign for the Democratic challenger, Representative Ron Klink, a moderate from suburban Pittsburgh. He raised some money for him, roughly $200,000, and gave Democratic hopes an extra boost when he labeled the Santorum seat ''worth fighting for.''

But those hopes slumped on Wednesday with the release of a poll that showed Mr. Santorum with a 2-to-1 lead over Mr. Klink. And they sagged even lower on Thursday with release of a campaign finance report that showed Mr. Santorum with nearly an 8-to-1 lead in campaign funds, $4.3 million to $564,500.

Putting the best face possible on the new reports, Democratic leaders noted that the finance report did not include the just-raised $200,000, and they pointed out that the poll found almost a third of all voters still undecided -- many because they knew little or nothing about Mr. Klink.
